Exaggerate: The claim may be seen as exaggerating the situation by stating that every Republican nominee since Richard Nixon has released their tax returns, when in fact Nixon himself did not release his tax returns in 1968 or 1972.
Understate: The claim may be seen as understating the significance of releasing tax returns by stating that presidential candidates are not required to release them, when in reality, it is a customary practice that helps the public vet a candidate's finances.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support to back up the statement that every Republican nominee since Richard Nixon has released their tax returns, as it only provides examples of nominees from the past nine presidential elections.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider alternative explanations for why the presumptive Republican nominee has refused to release his tax returns, such as the ongoing IRS audit or personal privacy concerns.
